title: Puppy farmer Sean Kerr jailed for making 'fortune' selling sick animals he knew could die | Metro News
text:
Jen Mills for Metro.co.uk Thursday 16 Feb 2017 4:31 pm Sean Kerr was banned from keeping dogs for life (Picture: SWNS) 
WARNING: Upsetting images. 
A puppy farmer has been jailed for six months for selling severely ill dogs to people who had no idea their new pet might not survive. Man caught on CCTV scratching 'V' on neighbour's Bentley 
Sean Kerr, 52, made a ‘small fortune’ by breeding the puppies in horrific conditions, making them sleep in pitch black sheds covered in faeces and urine then selling them for up to £400. 
Many of the animals were suffering from parvovirus, a potentially deadly virus which led to some of them dying or having to be put down shortly after they went to their new homes. 
When RSPCA inspectors visited the squalid kennels they found a dead puppy in a plastic shopping bag, next to old fizzy drinks cans and McDonald’s wrappers in the footwell of a Peugeot van outside. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video The puppies were kept in pitch black sheds (Picture: SWNS) 
He advertised the puppies, including pugs, bichon frises, cockapoos, shih tzus and chihuahuas, on the Pets4Homes website. 
But his business was brought to an end when the RSPCA raided Pastures Farm in Solihull, Birmgingham, on December 22, 2015 following a tip off. 10kg block of ice 'falls from plane' and smashes through man's garage roof 
They found 37 dogs there. Nine of them were pregnant, including a shih tzu which was found in a cramped downstairs toilet. 
Video from the raid shows how the animals suffered with barely any light, limited ventilation and unhygienic conditions while many of them were extremely sick. 
‘Toileting was done in the same area so faeces and urine were present in the same areas as sleeping and living,’ District Judge Shamim Quereshi said when Kerr appeared in court. One of the pregnant dogs was found in a toilet (Picture: SWNS) Inspectors found 37 dogs at the farm (Picture: SWNS) 
‘It was heartrending to hear from [witnesses] that they were looking forward to having the puppy they were buying which ended up either dying or having to be euthanised.’ 
Baby taken into care after father was heard talking about 'benefits of formula milk' One woman, Kim Bradley, bought two puppies for £650 and both died just days later. 
Anita Hutchings purchased a puppy for £325 after she saw it advertised on Pets4Homes, even though she said the puppy stank, had discoloured fur and was lethargic. 
‘She said there was something not quite right about it but she felt it was not getting any care and I think her heart ruled her mind when she decided to buy it,’ the judge said. 
‘With Miss Hutchings, it was a sinister motive [from Kerr] to hope that she would give you the money and then have the puppy dead within a couple of hours of buying. 
‘People thought they were buying from a caring home. They felt duty bound to care for a puppy, expecting that nobody else was going to care for them.’ Inspectors found a dead puppy in a plastic bag (Picture: SWNS) Many of the dogs had parvovirus (Picture: SWNS) The RSPCA acted following a tip-off (Picture: SWNS) 
District Judge Shamim Quereshi said: ‘Mr Kerr was motivated by a devious desire to keep the virus (parvovirus) quiet and avoid problems with the authorities rather than any genuine concern for the death of the puppy or its effect on a new owner. 
Trump reassures everyone by saying he wants to avoid a 'nuclear holocaust' ‘I have to sentence you considering the fact that you were earning a small fortune. 
‘You have sold these puppies using different names and mobile numbers. The whole operation was one of high levels of deceit.’ 
She said Mr Kerr knew full well his animals were ill and ‘was hoping the buyer would be naive or sentimental enough to buy it whilst he pocketed the profits.’ Sean Kerr, 51 and Louise St John Paulton, 42, leaving Birmingham Magistrates Court at a previous hearing (Picture: SWNS) The dogs had no separate area to go to the toilet and were sitting in urine and faeces (Picture: SWNS) 
‘I reject any notion that an animal left with an illness copes with it and therefore does not suffer.’ 
Governmental think tank proposes 'chill days' and 52 week paid sick days Henry Spooner, defending, said: ‘He is of good character and there is no suggestion that the dogs suffered from any cruel treatment.’ 
Louise St John Poulton, 42, was deemed unfit to stand trial as she was in hospital with a diabetes related illness. She is expected to stand trial at a later date. 
Kerr was found guilty of six counts of unnecessary suffering to dogs and three counts relating to improper animal welfare following a trial at Birmingham Magistrate’s Court. 
As well as being jailed, Kerr, now of Stoke-on-Trent, was also ordered to pay £30,000 in costs, an £80 victim surcharge, and was banned from keeping dogs for life. More
